quoteFirst: “I asked only because I’ve been reading and haven’t any idea what time of night it is.” He sat up and looked at the little clock on the nearer chiffonier. It was
quoteLast: according to the clock, but as the latter was frequently wrong he didn’t accept the evidence as conclusive. He laid back again, yawned, dropped the book to the floor and clasped his hands under his head. Chick, undressing, whistled cheerfully; almost too cheerfully Bert thought. “Have a good game?” the latter asked presently.
title: Right Half Hollins
author: Barbour, Ralph Henry, 1870-1944; Crump, Leslie, 1894-1962 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: For instance, Nikolaus would save Lisa from drowning. He would arrive on the scene at exactly the right moment--
quoteLast: , the long-ago appointed instant of time--and the water would be shoal, the achievement easy and certain. But he will arrive some seconds too late, now; Lisa will have struggled into deeper water.
title: The Mysterious Stranger: A Romance
author: Twain, Mark, 1835-1910; Wyeth, N. C. (Newell Convers), 1882-1945 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Furthermore, the tendency of English criticism is towards the very doctrines which the Greek grammarian wishes to get rid of. _We_ have the difficulty of a second conjugation: but, on the other hand, instead of
quoteLast: ses (an imperfect, perfect, pluperfect, and aorist), we have only one (the aorist). Now, when we find that good reasons can be given for supposing that the strong preterite in the Gothic languages was once a reduplicate perfect, we are at liberty to suppose that what is now the same tense under two forms, was, originally, different tenses.
title: The English Language
author: Latham, R. G. (Robert Gordon), 1812-1888

quoteFirst: In July, 1885, an engine with a train of three cars made a trip over the West Shore road which is the most extraordinary one on record. It started from East Buffalo, N. Y., at
quoteLast: , and reached Weehawken, N. J., at 7.27 P.M. Deducting the time consumed in stops, the actual running time was 7 hours and 23 minutes, or an average of 56 miles per hour. Between Churchville and Genesee Junction this train attained the unparalleled speed of 87 miles per hour, and at several other parts of the line a speed of from 70 to 80 miles an hour.
title: The American Railway: Its Construction, Development, Management, and Appliances
author: Clarke, Thomas Curtis, 1827-1901; Cooley, Thomas McIntyre, 1824-1898 [Author of introduction, etc.]

quoteFirst: "Sunday, 21st October. P.M. At 6 Cape Howe 5 leagues. At 3/
quoteLast: perceived a heavy gale coming on westward, up courses: shortened sail. At 11 strong gales with thunder and lightning and rain: hove to under balance: reefed main-sail.
title:
The Logbooks of the Lady Nelson
With the journal of her first commander Lieutenant James Grant
author: Lee, Ida, 1865-1943

quoteFirst: Stangerson had left the Darzacs at Dijon, where the whole party had arrived at twenty-seven minutes after six o’clock in the evening. The Professor had then taken the train which leaves Dijon at eight minutes past seven, and had arrived at Lyons at
quoteLast: and at Valence at forty-seven minutes after midnight. During the same time the Darzacs, leaving Dijon at seven o’clock, continued on their way to Modane, and, by way of Saint-Amour, reached Bourg at three minutes past nine in the evening, on the train which was scheduled to leave at eight minutes past nine. M.
title: The perfume of the lady in black
author: Leroux, Gaston, 1868-1927; Simont [Illustrator]
